ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PASSPORT ENDORSEMENT FOR SAF RESERVISTS
(Request for extension)


    1. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether the one-year inter-

Column: 6

national passport endorsement for reservists of the Singapore Armed Forces will be extended to three or more years.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the SAF is a national service army which depends critically on reservists. For operational reasons, it needs to be able to recall reservists at short notice. It therefore needs to know where each individual reservist is at all times.

    Strictly speaking, reservists should apply for exit permits for each one of their overseas trips. Up till 1981, MINDEF in fact required them to do so. Then MINDEF relaxed the rule. Reservists who go abroad for less than six months no longer need to apply for exit permits, although they still have to keep their units informed.

    However, MINDEF still requires reservists to renew their passports yearly, to help it to keep track of them, particularly when they are overseas. The measure is

Column: 7

also a good reminder to reservists of their role in Total Defence. It is not meant to restrict or discourage reservists from travelling or working abroad. Reservists who are working or studying overseas are liberally granted full passports for the duration of their employment or of their course.

     Dr Ong Chit Chung (Bukit Batok): Sir, I would like to ask whether the Minister is aware that many countries require a minimum of six months' validity of passports. Although they are given a one-year endorsement, in effect, they have only six months to use the passport before they required to extend the validity if they wish to travel to those countries. And this means a lot of inconvenience for many of our reservists who are in the business sector. Would the Minister consider extending, say, to two years if it is not possible to be longer?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware of this. I concede that there is some inconvenience involved in the renewing of passports every year. We have, in MINDEF, just recently reviewed the position as to whether we want to hold it at one year, or whether we want to extend it to two years. It is a question of judgment. In this review, we have decided to stay with one year. We can review it again in a year or two.

LOWER FLOOR HDB FLATS FOR AGED AND INFIRM


    2. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for National Development, with the Report of the Advisory Council on the Aged in mind, if the Housing and Development Board will consider reserving the bottom floors of high-rise public housing blocks for the aged and other persons who will suffer seriously from any lift failure.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB has a policy to give priority to an applicant to select a flat on a lift landing floor or on lower floors, if he or a family member is

Column: 8

physically handicapped. This priority is given during the selection of flat units. Based on HDB's records, the majority of cases given such priorities are aged persons.

    In anticipation of the increasing proportion of aged in our population, HDB is now building housing blocks with lifts on every floor. With the provision of lift landings on every floor, and the installation of better lifts which result in fewer failures, it would not be necessary to reserve flats on the lower floors exclusively for allocation to the aged and physically disabled. Nonetheless, the present priority scheme for selection of flats on the lower floors would still be maintained for the aged and the disabled.

PURCHASE OF HDB FLATS
(Relaxation of waiting period for private house owners)


    3. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for National Development if the Housing and Development Board will consider relaxing wholly or partially the requirement for owner-occupiers of private housing units to wait for two-and-a-half years after the sale of their only private property before they can purchase HDB flats, if they are senior citizens without children or living apart from their children or, alternatively, permitting former owner-occupiers of private housing units to rent HDB flats in the meantime.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, senior citizens who are owner-occupiers of private property can apply to purchase HDB flats upon selling their properties provided they satisfy the following criteria:

    (i) they have retired and are unemployed.

    (ii) they sold their only properties in order to use the proceeds to support themselves.

    Such senior citizens need not wait for 2(r) years to buy flats except that they are only allowed to purchase a HUDC flat or a resale flat in the open market or a new HDB flat in the outer sub-urban estates and new towns. If they wish to rent rather than

Column: 9

buy a HDB flat, their request can also be considered by the Board.

Column: 9

SPECIAL FACILITIES FOR SENIOR CITIZENS


    4. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Minister for National Development whether special facilities are developed for senior citizens in or around public housing estates.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1978, HDB embarked on a programme to provide barrier-free design in all its new developments to facilitate mobility of senior citizens and the physically disabled. The provisions have been mainly in the form of gentle ramps leading to carparks, lift lobbies, paths leading to other blocks or communal facilities. In the case of existing HDB estates, similar provisions are carried out under the 5-yearly Repairs and Redecoration Programme.

    Senior Citizens's corners have also been provided in almost all HDB estates for senior citizens to gather and interact during their leisure time. In addition, standard facilities provided in HDB estates such as void decks, bird-singing corners and neighbourhood parks can also serve the same purpose.

CHILDREN OF LOWER-INCOME FAMILIES
(Financial and Other assistance)


    The following Question stood in the name of Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe -

    5: To ask the Minister for Education (a) whether he will provide details of financial and other assistance schemes to children of families in the lower-income group to help them in their education at the primary and second level; and (b) whether his Ministry will consider providing free primary and secondary education to children of families with monthly take-home income of $600 and below.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): Sir, Question 5.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, primary school pupils, who are Singapore citizens or one of whose parents is a Singapore

Column: 10

citizen, do not pay any school fees. Pupils pay a miscellaneous fee of $4.00 per month. Pupils whose family income (excluding CPF contributions) does not exceed $350 per month can apply to pay the miscellaneous fee at half the normal rate. These pupils can also apply for a grant of free textbooks.

    Secondary school pupils pay a school fee of $5.00 per month and a miscellaneous fee of $5.50 per month. Pupils whose family income (again excluding CPF contributions) which does not exceed $350 per month can apply for remission of school fees and payment of miscellaneous fees at half the normal rate. These pupils can also apply for loan of textbooks. In addition, the Government awards bursaries for secondary education to bright but needy pupils.

    The Ministry of Education reviews the above financial assistance schemes for needy pupils regularly. The Ministry will consider extending the schemes to families with incomes of up to $600 per month if there is a need to do so.

TANJONG KATONG FLOOD ALLEVIATION PROGRAMME
(Completion date)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Choo Wee Khiang -

    6. To ask the Minister for the Environment when will the flood alleviation programme be completed in Tanjong Katong.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tiong Bahru GRC): Question 6, Sir.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the flood alleviation programme for the Tanjong Katong area is expected to be completed by end 1991.

    The work involves the reconstruction of two drainage pumping stations with higher capacity pumps, the widening and deepening of existing drains, and the raising of some low-lying roads. Work began in July last year and is currently in progress.

    Flooding in the Tanjong Katong area will be substantially alleviated with the completion of this project.

ILLEGAL ENTRY OF THAI WORKERS
(Measures to prevent)


    8. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Home Affairs why were there more than 2,000 Thai illegal workers found to have entered Singapore without proper travel documents at the time of their contact with the law and what stringent measures are being taken to ensure effective prevention of such illegal entry by foreigners.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, these illegal immigrants had entered Singapore landing on our coastline under the cover of darkness after a short boat trip from nearby staging points. With the help of well-organized trafficking syndicates, they were sometimes able to escape detection.

    In recent months, the Marine Police Division and the Immigration Department have stepped up patrols and surveillance to curb this trafficking. They have succeeded on several occasions to arrest traffickers and intercept these attempts to land illegal immigrants. For example, in December 1988, a ring leader was arrested and this was followed by another arrest in February 1989. In October 1988, a boatman with a female assistant was arrested while trying to land eight illegal immigrants near the Senoko Power Station. Another boatman was arrested at sea in January 1989

Column: 12

while attempting to convey 10 illegal immigrants.

    The Marine Police and Immigration will intensify their patrols and surveillance efforts on all potential landing sites to curb the activities of the trafficking syndicates.

    With the recent amendments to the Immigration Act, convicted illegal immigrants and those who overstay for more than 90 days will face mandatory imprisonment of 3 months and 3 strokes of the cane. Those trafficking in illegal immigrants or harbouring them are also subject to severe penalties: a mandatory minimum jail sentence of 2 years and mandatory caning for traffickers, and mandatory minimum jail sentence of 6 months and fine of up to $6,000 for harbourers.

    Our strategy to deal with illegal immigrants is to enhance our border security with more patrol and surveillance as well as to implement more effective deterrents such as caning for offenders. At the same time, we will also enforce the law against employers of illegalimmigrants and overstayers of more than 90 days. On conviction, they will face imprisonment and fines. These deterrent measures should reduce the inflow of illegal immigrants.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister whether the traffickers who bring in the illegal immigrants are Singaporeans or foreigners operating such activities from outside Singapore?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1988, 18 traffickers were prosecuted. Except for three who were Singaporeans, most of them were foreigners operating outside. And I am glad to say that we have received excellent cooperation from the Malaysian authorities who have not only helped us in investigations but have also helped us apprehend the culprits and extradite them to Singapore.

ILLEGAL ENTRY OF THAI WORKERS


    9. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Home Affairs how is it that about 10,000 Thai foreign workers could slip into Singapore and work here with forged documents undetected by his Ministry's enforcement officers.

Column: 13



     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, the 10,000 Thai foreign workers did not slip into Singapore with forged documents. Almost 80% of them entered Singapore lawfully with valid travel documents, ostensibly as tourists and then overstayed illegally in order to work here.

    Immigration officers handle about 45,000 arrivals per day at the Woodlands Checkpoint. In 1988, they refused entry to 13,500 persons who could not satisfy Immigration Officers that they were bona fide tourists. However, Immigration Officers cannot detect every visitor who intends to overstay and work illegally, no matter how vigilant they may be.

    As this House was informed during the debate on the Second Reading of the Immigration (Amendment) Bill in January, this matter was brought to the attention of this House. And the Government has been very concerned with the problem of illegal immigrants for the past two years. It knew the numbers were large. This House was informed that, in 1988 alone, 4,120 overstayers were arrested. This House was also informed that 17% of our prison population were immigration offenders. For every overstayer arrested, many more were evading detection.

    The Police and Immigration Departments would have required a sustained massive effort to round up all these illegal immigrants. Illegal workers, including those with forged work permits, move from worksite to worksite, merging with other foreign workers who have proper work permits. Errant employers deliberately keep no records to avoid being implicated.

    This was why the Government amended the Immigration Act to provide for caning for illegal immigrants who overstayed more than 90 days, and for a presumption clause to enable us to prosecute their employers. Those 10,000 illegal immigrants and overstayers virtually voluntarily surrendered to be repatriated before the amendments came into force shows that these measures were both necessary and effective.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Could the Minister please comment on the report that many of them who overstayed

Column: 14

had forged documents. How does this come about?

     Prof. Jayakumar: This comes about because there are syndicates who are engaged in forged documents. And when we catch them, they will be severely punished. Indeed, quite a number of cases are being investigated and are dealt with by the Commercial Crime Department. In other words, forgery of work permits is an offence. Investigations also are commenced whenever we have information on individuals or syndicates working in forged work permits. In fact, some of those who are trafficking in illegal immigrants are also engaged in forgery of work permits, and action will also be taken against them.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, this question is put because of the large number of overstayers and also ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, can you ask your question?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, What is more important is that these people who overstayed, according to the reports, were able to go undetected because of the documents which they have. So I thought the Minister's reply should give us a clearer view as to what exactly is done to get rid of these syndicates. I mean if there are a lot of foreigners around here with forged documents, it is a serious problem for Singapore.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Indeed, Sir, it is a serious matter and it is because the Government felt it was a serious matter that we came to this House to ask for more powers, more penalties, to enable us to deal effectively with this serious problem. I recall the Member speaking against the measures to introduce caning. He was not the only one. Others too. But if we had not adopted those measures, a question which Members must ask themselves is: would they have voluntarily surrendered? As I said in my answer, these persons who came into Singapore at the checkpoint had valid passports and valid travel documents. It is after they enter Singapore on valid social visit pass that they decide to overstay and work illegally, some without any forged documents, some with forged documents.

Column: 15



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, the Minister will remember that during the debate on the amendment to the Immigration Act he did not mention or even give a hint that so great a number of illegal immigrants were moving around Singapore with forged documents. There was no hint of that. So if the Minister had said, "Look, about 10,000 of these immigrants, which is a large number, moving around Singapore with forged documents ---

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, can you ask your question? I think you are engaging in a debate. Ask your question.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: The reason I did not support the Bill is because it is a draconian step.

     Mr Speaker: Mr Chiam, what is your question?

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Cheng San GRC): You support now?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: So I think the Minister has not really given a proper answer as to the seriousness of this problem. I think he has not dealt with it.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Chiam is a lawyer. He should know that under the Immigration Act it is clearly defined that an overstayer is a person who came in on a valid social visit pass and has overstayed. Whether or not he has a forged work permit or not, he still is an overstayer.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: That was not a problem. That was never mentioned.

     Prof. Jayakumar: As far as immigration is concerned, if he had overstayed, he had committed an offence, whether or not he has any other forged documents. If you are an illegal immigrant and you have entered Singapore either without travel documents or with forged travel documents, then that is an offence of illegal entry. What happens after you enter into Singapore, whether you managed to get a forged document is irrelevant for the purpose of investigating and apprehending that person. If he has entered Singapore with travel documents he is an illegal immigrant. If he has entered Singapore validly and thereafter overstayed, he has committed an offence of overstaying.

Column: 16

What he does after that is irrelevant, he has still committed an offence, and that is how the problem arose and was put to this House.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Can the Minister tell us whether or not these 10,000 were, in fact, employed originally by the MRTC? Or employed to construct the MRT? Now that the project for the MRT has been completed, they have stayed over.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am really surprised that a Member of this House ---

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am asking you.

     Prof. Jayakumar: I will give him the answer. I am surprised that a Member of this House should come here and repeat such unfounded allegations ---

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Then say so.

     Prof. Jayakumar: --- made in a foreign press, critical of Singapore.

     Mr Speaker: Order. I would like to inform Mr Chiam, if you have asked the question I think you should wait for the reply before interjecting again. You may continue, Prof Jayakumar.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Thank you, Sir. The innuendo is that we knew of these offenders and deliberately did not take any action, which is not true. As early as November 1987, the Singapore Embassy in Bangkok issued a statement of the penalties which were then in force and informing all those who were reading the Thai newspapers and this was published in the Bangkok Post. This was as long ago as 1987. In February 1989 the Thai MFA issued further press releases. So it is not a case of suddenly taking action only now.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I think I have to put on record that the Minister should not take objection to me asking that question. He should thank me for it because now he is given the opportunity to clear the air and put aside all rumours. I think the Minister should thank me for it.

     Mr Chandra Das: We thank you for rumour-mongering.

RETIREES' INCOME
(Tax concessions)


    10. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Finance, in respect of retirees, whether he will consider (i) allowing interest earned from their savings tax-free, subject to a maximum to be fixed by his Ministry and (ii) allowing tax deduction for their medical expenses.

     The Minister of State for Finance (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo) (for the Minister for Finance): Sir, the Member for Ang Mo Kio asked whether the Finance Minster would consider allowing the interests earned by retirees from their savings to be tax-free, subject to a maximum amount.

    I would like to first point out that we cannot exempt from tax the interests earned by retirees from their savings. This is because such exemption could lead to tax avoidance schemes such as placing funds in the names of retirees. Secondly, I would like to point out that retirees are also entitled to the personal relief of $2,000, like everyone else. This means that a retiree's income - if it is only interests from savings alone - will not be taxed unless it exceeds $2,000. Additional relief of up to $6,000 per year is also available to the retiree if he tops up his own CPF account to the Minimum Sum. Income from annuities purchased under the Minimum Sum Scheme, and interests from the POSB, are also tax-exempt. In regard to cases where the savings are indeed substantial and taxable interests earned do exceed $2,000, I should point out the tax rate for chargeable income of up to $5,000 is less than 3%.

    The Member for Ang Mo Kio also asked whether the Finance Minister would consider allowing tax deduction for medical expenses of retirees.

    Sir, this is a question of how we should help the needy retirees. Government policy has been that children should be encouraged to look after their aged parents. For this purpose, children have been allowed to use their Medisave balances to pay for their parents' medical expenses, and the tax relief for maintaining parents has been increased. Tax

Column: 18

deduction for retirees for their own medical expenses is also not appropriate because the financially needy retiree would have little or no assessable income for deduction.

    Nevertheless, I would like to assure Members that no citizen would be denied medical attention simply because he cannot afford it. The Finance Ministry administers a remission scheme for those who cannot afford their medical fees.

GEYLANG EAST SWIMMING COMPLEX
(Repairs and renovation works)


    11. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister for Community Development (a) if he will provide a progress report of the repairs and renovation works which are being carried out by the Singapore Sports Council at the Geylang East Swimming Complex; and (b) when the works are expected to be completed and the Complex opened for use by the public.

     The Minister of State for Community Development (Dr Seet Ai Mee) (for the Minister for Community Development): MrSpeaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The renovation works at the Geylang East Swimming Complex are undertaken by the HDB. They involve building and structural works and improvement to the filtration system.

    As at end March 1989, 40% of the renovation works have been completed. The renovations are scheduled for completion by end December 1989.

    When completed, defects in the concrete pavement, perimeter drain, shower points and footbaths will be rectified. The pressure sand filters will be reconditioned. Water circulating pumps, chlorination equipment and underground distribution pipes and fittings will be replaced.

    The Singapore Sports Council will need another two months to run in the renovated swimming complex before re-opening it for public use sometime in March 1990.

PUBLIC UTILITIES BOARD
(Privatization)


    12. Dr Ow Chin Hock asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if a decision has been made to privatise the Public Utilities Board and, if so, whether any problems will be encountered and how he proposes to deal with them.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government is considering privatizing selected statutory boards in order to:

    (a) Broaden the stock market;

    (b) Provide quality investments to enable more Singaporeans to own stocks in good local companies; and

    (c) Give the companies greater freedom to operate, and to become more market oriented in their provision of services.

    The privatizing exercise is not to:

    (a) Raise money; or

    (b) to get rid of inefficient and loss-making organizations by turning them over to the private sector.

    There is no need to privatize statutory boards hastily. Statutory boards should be privatized at the opportune time and floated in the market at a pace that the market can absorb.

    The PUB engaged consultants to study the privatization of its electicity and gas operations. It did not consider privatizing the water operations, because of the sensitive and strategic nature of Singapore's water supply.

    The consultants have reported that it is feasible to privatize PUB's electricity and gas operations. Since the PUB, unlike government-owned utilities in some other countries, does not suffer from the gross inefficiencies, privatization is unlikely to yield immediate gains in performance or efficiency. It will, however, give us the general advantages of privatization mentioned above.

Key considerations

    Before I go into the provisions of the Bill, it may be useful, Sir, to recapitulate some of the reasons why we cannot continue with appeals to the Privy Council in the way we have had them for so many years.

    First, very few Commonwealth countries retain their links with the Privy Council. In Asia, apart from Brunei, Singapore is the only independent country to have appeals to the Privy Council. India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Malaysia have a long time ago cut off appeals to the Privy Council. In the South Pacific, Australia has done away with appeals and New Zealand, whose culture, heritage and political system is most akin to United Kingdom, is also proposing to do away with appeals to the Privy Council.

    On 16th September 1963 when Singapore's direct administrative links with Britain were severed upon our joining Malaysia, our economic, social and political developments have been on divergent paths when compared to the United Kingdom. This underscores two points. First, our laws must meet the problems and conditions of Singapore's circumstances. Secondly, these laws are best understood and interpreted by judges who are a part of our society and who share our history and our culture.

    True, we have allowed Privy Council appeals to continue from colonial days because we valued the ability and erudition of their judges. But we have to recognize that because judges of the United Kingdom have no experience of our own circumstances, it is inevitable that they must draw on their own history, their own culture when reviewing our cases. Furthermore, judicial attitudes and values in our respective societies have also diverged as

    First, United Kingdom's entry into the European Community. The divergence between United Kingdom and Singapore's legal systems has increased over the years especially since 1973 when the United Kingdom joined the European Community, and when it did so, the European Community law became automatically part of United Kingdom law and was directly applicable in United Kingdom, creating rights and duties for individuals. And where there is inconsistency between Community law and the law of a member state of the European Community, Community law prevails.

This supremacy of Community law is emphasized by this fact that the House of Lords in United Kingdom is no longer the court of final appeal in the United Kingdom. In matters concerning the interpretation of the European Community treaties, the validity and interpretation of acts and statutes of the Community institutions, it is the Court of Justice of the European Communities which is now the supreme tribunal. Its decisions in these areas are binding on all United Kingdom courts including the House of Lords.

    Now, Singapore is not in Europe and all these developments which have affected United Kingdom legal trends arising from its membership of the European Community are not relevant to us and are totally different from our situation.
